title: 12 ways to improve turn-based RPG combat systems
blurb: A list of twelve ways to change-up your RPG combat system to set it apart. Focuses on emergent complexity, clarity, determinism, and tactics.

title: How to make a modern game that feels like a classic JRPG
blurb: A look at what made classic 16-bit JRPGs so great, and how to implement those in your own RPG. Stories are the key. Combat should be puzzle-like.

title: Why are character-classes used in game design?
blurb: Benefits of adding classes to your game and how they impact the overall game design and balancing.

title: How to Start Designing Games
blurb: A thorough introduction to the fundamentals of game design, and how to implement them in your game.

title: How To Perfect Your Gameâ€™s Core Loop
blurb: How to design the core game loop and surrounding game loops to focus on the fun in your game.

title: The 13 Basic Principles of Gameplay Design
blurb: 13 fundamental principles of game design, with system, level, and UI design examples.

title: How to Make an RPG: Levels
blurb: Why RPGs include levels, formulas from existing games, and how to write the right formulas for your game.

title: Getting Started in Automated Game Design
blurb: A detailed introduction to automated game design: writing code that designs game mechanics for you.

title: Are Lives Outdated Game Design?
blurb: Older games use lives or checkpoints, which cause frustration when replaying, but it's useful for procedural games. What other methods can replace lives?

title: 7 Game Design Mistakes to Avoid
blurb: Seven common game design mistakes, including: thinking too big, ignoring onboarding tutorials, being too committed to an idea, igoring polish, and including random things.

title: Downwell's Dual Purpose Design
blurb: All game elements in Downwell serve two or more purposes, which creates emergent gameplay and difficult choices for the player.

title: How to Get Your Game to Done
blurb: Many games don't make it to completion. An analysis of some common reasons games fail, and some ways to give your games a better chance at finishing.

title: Game Design in Open-World
blurb: Open world games are difficult to design because you don't know where the player will go. Two solutions to the player-power vs. world-power difficulty.

title: The Brilliance of Bastion's Flexible Builds
blurb: Lessons learned from Bastion, which is designed to allow player flexibility and experimentation with different builds.

title: What is 'Souls-Like'?
blurb: A list of several key characteristics that make a game 'souls-like' as well as others that are often used but not key.

title: What makes a Souls-like (and why the definition is important)
blurb: An opinion on six of the key defining characteristics of souls-like games, and how a few souls-like games implement them.

title: Mitigating complexity and toxicity: A look at League of Legends
blurb: A look at Leage of Legends and how to reduce community toxicity in it, and in MOBAs in general, by changing the game design

title: Scroll Back: The Theory and Practice of Cameras in Side-Scrollers
blurb: A thorough reference of several different styles of cameras in 2D games, and how they work.

title: How To Balance An RPG
blurb: How to design your RPG character classes so that they're mechanically interesting; how to deal with trash items; and using spreadsheets and formulas for balancing.

title: Game NPC Design - Why We Relate to A Pile of Code and Pixels
blurb: A discussion on how adding a bit of detail to your NPCs such as a backstory or personality quirks can make them appear more life-like and interesting instead of generic place-holders.

title: Numbers Getting Bigger: The Design and Math of Incremental Games
blurb: An in-depth look at the design of idle and incremental games, including: discovery, multiple sources, exponential cost, offline play, plater optimization, and prestige.

title: The Roguelike Lessons that Horror Design Needs to Learn
blurb: Some lessons horror games can learn from roguelikes, about pacing, random, repetition, and fighting; and a look at micro-horror.

title: A Good Puzzle Game Is Hard To Build
blurb: Six tips on how to build a good puzzle game, including: helping the player along, learning over solving, exploring level designs, minimalism, and the role of a central game mechanic.

title: Game Design Perspective: Stardew Valley
blurb: A look at what makes Stardew Valley such a well-designed game: variety (small and large), activities overlap, and delayed rewards.

title: The Design of Mario Odyssey's Cascade Kingdom
blurb: Super Mario Odyssey is fun from the get-go, by following three principles: multiple options, clear objectives, and increasingly-difficult uses of mechanics.

title: Top 7 Idle Game Mechanics
blurb: A brief look at seven sub-genres of idle games, and some of the game design pros and cons of each sub-genre. Linear clickers, arcade, merge games, management games, simulations, RPGs, and story-driven idle games.

title: How do I come up with the game mechanics for a puzzle game?
blurb: How to come up with ame mechanics ideas? Play games, start small, copy others. Experiment, iterate until it's great.

title: Balancing Turn-Based RPGs: The Big Picture
blurb: How to balance a JRPG from a high-level: knowing your audience, adjusting difficulty vs. intended game time, progression, and balance.

title: The Psychological Trick That Can Make Rewards Backfire
blurb: Achievements and designer-made quests are extrinsic rewards, which can backfire and demotivate exploration and experimentation. Leaderboards and personal bests work for instric rewards.

title: What is a Broughlike?
blurb: Description of common game design elements in broughlikes, which are highly-compressed roguelikes on small boards.

title: The Reset Problem: A Case for Single-player Matchmaking
blurb: In single-player games, players die, restart, and often have to grind through boring/easy content. Players don't get to practice long at their highest skill level. There are some game-design solutions to that: dynamic difficulty, and single-player matchmaking.
